user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(uint32 ModeBits)
{
    char param[32];

    if (OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.EnableTermControl)
    {
        if (ModeBits == OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("sgr0", NULL);
        }
        else
        {
            if ((ModeBits & OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT) == 0)
            {
                /* no highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("rmso", NULL);
            }
            else
            {
                /* set highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("smso", NULL);
            }

            snprintf(param, sizeof(param), "%d", OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(ModeBits));
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
static void OS_BSP_ExecTput(const char *cap, const char *param)
{
    pid_t cpid;
    int   status;

    cpid = fork();
    if (cpid < 0)
    {
        return;
    }
    if (cpid == 0)
    {
        execlp("tput", "tput", cap, param, NULL);
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    waitpid(cpid, &status, 0);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl and the related helper OS_BSP_ExecTput. None of the code uses memcmp. There are no comparisons of null-terminated strings using memcmp (only integer comparisons of ModeBits and bitwise operations). The only string operations are snprintf to format a numeric parameter and passing string literals/parameters to execlp; there are no strcmp/strncmp/memcmp calls present. Therefore there are no code fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 to report.
